Asynchronous Wireless Federated Learning with Probabilistic Client Selection

Jiarong Yang, Yuan Liu, Fangjiong Chen, Wen Chen, and Changle Li This paper was supported in part by the National Key Research and Development Program of China under Grant 2020YFB1807700, in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61971196, U2001210, and 62071296, and in part by Shanghai 22JC1404000, 20JC1416502, and PKX2021-D02. Corresponding authors: Yuan Liu and Fangjiong Chen. Jiarong Yang, Yuan Liu and Fangjiong Chen are with school of Electronic and Information Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510641, China (e-mails: eejryang@mail.scut.edu.cn, eeyliu@scut.edu.cn, eefjchen@scut.edu.cn). Wen Chen is with Department of Electronic Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China (e-mail: wenchen@sjtu.edu.cn). Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a promising distributed learning framework where distributed clients collaboratively train a machine learning model coordinated by a server. To tackle the stragglers issue in asynchronous FL, we consider that each client keeps local updates and probabilistically transmits the local model to the server at arbitrary times. We first derive the (approximate) expression for the convergence rate based on the probabilistic client selection. Then, an optimization problem is formulated to trade off the convergence rate of asynchronous FL and mobile energy consumption by joint probabilistic client selection and bandwidth allocation. We develop an iterative algorithm to solve the non-convex problem globally optimally. Experiments demonstrate the superiority of the proposed approach compared with the traditional schemes.

Index Terms:
Asynchronous federated learning, stragglers, wireless networks.

I Introduction

The burgeoning of the Internet of Things (IoT) and the fifth generation mobile communication (5G) technology are driving the era of the Internet of Everything (IoE). Smartphones, wearable devices, smart homes, and various distributed wireless sensors generate massive amounts of data in real time [1, 2, 3], which can be used by machine learning techniques to bring diverse artificial intelligence (AI) services to people [4, 5, 6]. However, traditional machine learning is based on centralized training that requires sending all raw data to servers [7, 8], which can drain the wireless bandwidth and cause long communication delays. In addition, with the increasing public concern about data security and privacy issues, people or companies are not willing to share their private data, which leads to the problem of data islands [9]. To address the aforementioned issues, a promising distributed machine learning framework called federated learning (FL) has been proposed [10, 11]. A typical FL consists of a server and multiple clients with computation capabilities, in which the server only aggregates local models trained at the client side to obtain the global model. By decentralizing model training to the client side, FL not only preserves the data privacy, but also uses the computation capabilities of clients [12].

FL always assumes synchronous client-server communication, where the server waits to receive all local models of clients for model aggregation. However, with limited bandwidth (computation) resources, some clients may suffer from high communication (computation) latency and thus slow down convergence rate of the whole system [13]. This is known as stragglers. Asynchronous FL can naturally solve the stragglers issue, where the server aggregates local models without waiting for the delayed clients [14, 15, 16, 17, 13, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22]. However, discarding stragglers in asynchronous FL [22, 21] will cause serious performance degradation. Specifically, on the one hand, if stragglers do not receive the global model broadcast by the server due to network failure (e.g., channel fading), they cannot perform local training and communicate with the server. Thus stragglers not only violate participation fairness but also may drift the global model towards local optimum [23]. On the other hand, the gradients of stragglers based on the stale global model may also degrade the model performance [17, 22]. To solve this problem, the authors in [13] propose a scheme that clients can keep local model training based on the last received global model and send the updated local model to the server at arbitrary time. In this paper, we consider this asynchronous FL scenario in wireless networks.

As the synchronous case, the asynchronous FL also faces energy-efficiency problem in wireless networks, as mobile clients are usually with limited battery capacity while the transmission of local models is significant energy consuming. In addition, over-participation of some clients may hurt the model performance, i.e., too much participation of a certain group of clients may “drift” the global model to local optimum [24, 23, 25]. On the other hand, increasing the client participants could improve the model convergence [10]. This problem is known as the client selection that is used as an important method to deal with energy efficiency [26, 27] and data heterogeneity [28], i.e., selecting the clients with the most informativeness and/or the least communication overhead to participate in training. Note that client selection is more difficult in considered asynchronous FL with continuous local training and arbitrary communication. Specifically, in traditional (both synchronous and asynchronous) FL, client selection is performed regularly at the beginning of each round, and clients are selected to participate in training in a deterministic way, i.e., the server gathers the network information to calculate the selection or scheduling policy and then selects clients centrally. Whereas, in considered asynchronous FL, where clients can send their updated local models to server at arbitrary times, every client can be selected by a probability at each time. In other words, the server only calculates the selection probability for clients, and each client autonomously decides whether to send updated local model to server based on its selection probability. This refers to as probabilistic client selection in this paper. However, how to use probabilistic client selection to handle energy efficiency and data heterogeneity has no attention.

I-A Contributions

In this paper, we study the stragglers issue of asynchronous FL by joint probabilistic client selection and bandwidth allocation, where the clients keep local updates and exchange models with the server at arbitrary times. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We analyze the convergence rate of the asynchronous FL with probabilistic client selection, which exhibits the relationship between the training performance and participation probability of the clients. In particular, we consider an individual interval that each client must communicate with the server at least once, so as to adapt channel diversity and participation fairness.

  • •

    We formulate a joint optimization problem of probabilistic client selection and bandwidth allocation to trade off the convergence performance of the asynchronous FL and energy consumption of the clients. We use the sum-of-ratios algorithm to transform the original non-convex problem into a convex subtractive form and develop an iterative algorithm to find the globally optimal solutions.

  • •

    Several useful insights are obtained via our analysis: First, more frequent client-server communication can accelerate the model convergence. Second, fair participation of clients can also improve the model performance. Third, more clients benefit model performance, but if the number of clients exceed a certain threshold, the model performance degrades due to data heterogeneity. Fourth, the proposed scheme not only enhances both model performance and energy efficiency, but also improves fairness of energy consumption among clients.

I-B Prior Work

Wireless resource allocation and client selection for synchronous FL has been extensively studied [29, 26, 27, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36], with the goal of achieving higher model accuracy or lower energy/latency cost with limited resources. For example, the authors in [29] consider joint client selection and bandwidth allocation to maximize the model accuracy obtained in a limited training time. The authors in [26] show that selecting more clients at the end of training phase is beneficial for model accuracy improvement, and then propose an energy-aware client selection and bandwidth allocation algorithm. The authors in [27] consider an over-the-air FL with dynamic client selection to minimize the convergence bound while meeting energy constraints. In [30], the maximum model accuracy is achieved by weighting local updates for global parameter aggregation under a given resource budget. In [33], an age-based selection policy is proposed to jointly consider the staleness of the received parameters and the instantaneous channel qualities. Furthermore, client selection based on data importance has been employed to optimize the performance of FL in wireless networks [37, 38, 39]. Specifically, the importance metric of data in [37] incorporates both the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and data uncertainty. [38] utilizes gradient divergence to quantify the importance of each local update. And in [39], the importance of data is quantified by calculating the inner product between each local gradient and the ground-truth global gradient. In addition, client selection with the consideration of fairness is studied in [23, 40], where the probability of selecting each client is ensured by introducing a fairness constraint.

Asynchronous FL has been extensively studied to address the stragglers issue. In [14] and [15] the local updates uploaded by clients are adaptively weighted based on their staleness, aiming to alleviate the impact of stragglers on model performance. In [16], the number of local epochs is dynamically adjusted with the estimation of staleness to improve the model convergence. In [17], a dynamic learning strategy for step size adaptation on local training is proposed to reduce the impact of staleness caused by stragglers. In [13], an asynchronous version of local stochastic gradient descent (SGD) is studied, wherein the clients can communicate with the server at arbitrary time intervals. The above asynchronous FL works do not consider wireless networks.

There are some researches on asynchronous FL over wireless networks [18, 19, 21, 20]. For example, The authors in [18] propose three client selection strategies that maximize the expected number of effective training samples. In [19], a semi-asynchronous FL is proposed to minimize the training completion time, where the server aggregates local models based on their arrival order. In [20], an adaptive client selection algorithm is proposed to minimize training latency while taking into account the client availability and long-term fairness. The staleness of local models and the delays of local model training and uploading are considered in [21]. However, the works [18, 19, 20] assume that the fixed number of clients are scheduled for aggregation. And in [21], stragglers are discarded if they cannot transmit within a period. Unlike [18, 19, 21, 20], in our paper, clients probabilistically participate in the training and independently decide whether to upload their local updates.

It is necessary to compare our paper with the work [13] which considers the same asynchronous FL scenario of continuous local updates and arbitrary communication. First, the work [13] focuses on convergence analysis based on the assumption that all clients communicate with the server at the same frequency, while our paper gets away from this impractical assumption and obtains the new results. Second, our paper focuses on client selection and bandwidth allocation, which are not considered in [13]. To sum up, our paper and [13] consider the same asynchronous FL scenario but different assumptions and focuses, thus the two works are fundamentally different.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we present the system model. We analyze the convergence rate and formulate the optimization problem in Section III. An optimal algorithm to solve the formulated problem is proposed in Section IV. Finally, the experiment results and conclusions are provided in Section V and Section VI, respectively.

II System Model

In this section, we describe the system model for asynchronous FL over wireless networks. The main notations used in this paper are summarized in Table I.

II-A Asynchronous FL Model

We consider an asynchronous FL system comprising a server and K𝐾K clients indexed by 𝒦={1,2,⋯,K}𝒦12⋯𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}. According to the FL framework, a global statistical model is trained in a distributed manner to minimize a global loss function as follows:

min𝒙⁡f​(𝒙)=1K​∑k=1Kfk​(𝒙),subscript𝒙𝑓𝒙1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑓𝑘𝒙\displaystyle\min\limits_{\bm{x}}f(\bm{x})=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}f_{k}(\bm{x}), (1)

where 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} denotes the global model parameters and fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} is the local loss function based on the data set on client k𝑘k. We consider an asynchronous FL scenario, in which all clients update the local models at all time but send the latest gradients to the server at arbitrary times. Specifically, for client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t, we use 𝒙k,tsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\bm{x}_{k,t} to denote the local model parameters and 𝒚k,tsubscript𝒚𝑘𝑡\bm{y}_{k,t} to denote the global model parameters received by client k𝑘k before round t𝑡t. Then the actual gradient descent direction of client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t is defined as a pseudo-gradient [41, 42] as follows

𝜹k,t=𝒙k,t−𝒚k,t−1.subscript𝜹𝑘𝑡subscript𝒙𝑘𝑡subscript𝒚𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{\delta}_{k,t}=\bm{x}_{k,t}-\bm{y}_{k,t-1}. (2)

The server receives the gradients sent by the clients and updates the global parameters as follows:

𝒙t=𝒙t−1+1K​∑k∈Ct𝜹k,t,subscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝒙𝑡11𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝜹𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\bm{x}_{t}=\bm{x}_{t-1}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in C_{t}}\bm{\delta}_{k,t}, (3)

where Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t} denotes the set of clients who communicate with (or send gradients to) the server at round t𝑡t. After updating the global model, the sever broadcasts the updated parameters to the clients in Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}.

Note that in traditional synchronous FL, only the selected clients perform local training at each round, whereas in considered asynchronous FL, all clients keep local training and send their local pseudo-gradients to the server at arbitrary times. To overcome the stragglers issue as mentioned in Section I, we restrict that each client k𝑘k must communicate with the server at least once within period ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k}. By setting a reasonable ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} for each client, it ensures that each client can transmit its local pseudo-gradient to the server at the appropriate time.

II-B Communication Model

We consider orthogonal uplink channel access with total bandwidth W𝑊W, where the bandwidth allocated to client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t is wk,t​Wsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑊w_{k,t}W and wk,tsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k,t} is the bandwidth allocation ratio, satisfying 0≤wk,t≤10subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡10\leq w_{k,t}\leq 1 and ∑k=1Kwk,t≤1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1\sum_{k=1}^{K}w_{k,t}\leq 1 for each round t𝑡t. Denote Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} as the transmit power of client k𝑘k, hk,tsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k,t} as the uplink channel gain at round t𝑡t, and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} as the noise power density. Thus, the achievable transmission rate (bits/s) of client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t is given as

Rk,t=wk,t​W​log⁡(1+Pk​hk,twk,t​W​N0).subscript𝑅𝑘𝑡subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑊1subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑊subscript𝑁0\displaystyle R_{k,t}=w_{k,t}W\log\left(1+\frac{P_{k}h_{k,t}}{w_{k,t}WN_{0}}\right). (4)

Define pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} as the probability of client k𝑘k communicating with the server at round t𝑡t, we can obtain the total expected energy consumption (Joule) at round t𝑡t as

Et=∑k=1Kpk,t​Pk​SRk,t,subscript𝐸𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝑃𝑘𝑆subscript𝑅𝑘𝑡\displaystyle E_{t}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{p_{k,t}P_{k}S}{R_{k,t}}, (5)

where S𝑆S is the size (in bits) of model parameters that are the same for all clients. Note that here we only consider the communication/transmission energy, but the energy consumption of local model training, i.e., computing energy, can be easily involved since it is a constant during the training process.

II-C Protocol of Asynchronous FL

In asynchronous FL networks, the server optimizes the client selection probability {pk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K} and the bandwidth allocation ratio {wk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{w_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K}. At each round, the server broadcasts the client selection probability {pk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K} to all clients. Clients then decide whether to send their gradients based on {pk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K}, where clients who decide to communicate with the server transmit local pseudo-gradients on allocated channels with the bandwidth allocation ratio {wk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{w_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K}. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the specific steps of protocol can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    Step 1: All clients compute the local pseudo-gradients as (2).

  • •

    Step 2: The server calculates the client selection probability {pk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K} and the bandwidth allocation ratio {wk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{w_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K}, and broadcasts the client selection probability {pk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K} to all clients.

  • •

    Step 3: The clients decide whether to send local pseudo-gradients based on the client selection probability {pk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{p_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K}.

  • •

    Step 4: The client k∈Ct𝑘subscript𝐶𝑡k\in C_{t} sends the local pseudo-gradients to the server via a sub-channel with the bandwidth allocation ratio {wk,t}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑘1𝐾\{w_{k,t}\}_{k=1}^{K}.

  • •

    Step 5: The server updates the global model parameters as (3) and broadcasts the updated model to the clients k∈Ct𝑘subscript𝐶𝑡k\in C_{t}.

III Convergence Analysis and Problem Formulation

In this section, we first analyze the convergence rate of the proposed asynchronous FL scheme and derive an approximate expression with respect to the client selection probability. Then a joint optimization problem of probabilistic client selection and bandwidth allocation is presented to trade off convergence rate and energy consumption for the asynchronous FL.

III-A Convergence Analysis

In this subsection, we analyze the convergence rate of the proposed asynchronous FL scheme, which is the basis of the problem formulation. Firstly, we introduce the maximum communication interval ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} between each client k𝑘k and the server and then derive the convergence rate. Then we approximate the ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} in terms of the client selection probability {pk,t}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{p_{k,t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1} and reveal the relationship between {pk,t}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{p_{k,t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1} and the convergence rate of the model.

Before the convergence analysis, we first introduce the following assumptions.

Assumption 1.

Denote ∇Fk,t∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑡\nabla F_{k,t} as a gradient computed by client k𝑘k using SGD at round t𝑡t and it is also an unbiased stochastic gradient of fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} at 𝐱k,tsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑡\bm{x}_{k,t}, satisfying 𝔼​[∇Fk,t]=∇fk​(𝐱k,t)𝔼delimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝐱𝑘𝑡\mathbb{E}[\nabla F_{k,t}]=\nabla f_{k}(\bm{x}_{k,t}). We assume that

  • •

    Each local loss function fk​(𝒙)subscript𝑓𝑘𝒙f_{k}(\bm{x}) is L-smooth, i.e., ‖fk​(𝒙)−fk​(𝒙′)‖≤L​‖𝒙−𝒙′‖normsubscript𝑓𝑘𝒙subscript𝑓𝑘superscript𝒙′𝐿norm𝒙superscript𝒙′\|f_{k}(\bm{x})-f_{k}(\bm{x}^{\prime})\|\leq L\|\bm{x}-\bm{x}^{\prime}\|, for any 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} and 𝒙′superscript𝒙′\bm{x}^{\prime}.

  • •

    For any k𝑘k and 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, the norm of ∇Fk,t∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑡\nabla F_{k,t} can be bounded by 𝔼​[‖∇Fk,t‖]2≤𝐆m​a​x2𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]norm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝐆𝑚𝑎𝑥2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F_{k,t}\|]^{2}\leq\mathbf{G}_{max}^{2}.

  • •

    For any k𝑘k, the difference between ∇Fk,t∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑡\nabla F_{k,t} and ∇fk​(𝒙k,t)∇subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\nabla f_{k}(\bm{x}_{k,t}) can be bounded by 𝔼​[‖∇Fk,t−∇fk​(𝒙k,t)‖2]≤σ2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑡2superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F_{k,t}-\nabla f_{k}(\bm{x}_{k,t})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}.

Here 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅\mathbb{E}[\cdot] is the expectation of the randomness results from stochastic gradients. The first assumption is widely used in in the literature of convergence analysis for FL [29, 30, 43], while the second and the third assumptions are standard assumptions in the SGD literature [44, 45].

By assigning each client an individual maximum communication interval ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k}, the convergence rate of asynchronous FL is shown in the following Lemma.

Lemma 1.

When Assumptions 1 holds, given the maximum communication interval Δk,k∈{1,2,⋯,K}subscriptΔ𝑘𝑘12⋯𝐾\Delta_{k},k\in\{1,2,\cdots,K\} and η≤18​L𝜂18𝐿\eta\leq\frac{1}{8L}, the convergence rate of asynchronous FL is given by

where L𝐿L, 𝐆m​a​xsubscript𝐆𝑚𝑎𝑥\mathbf{G}_{max}, and σ𝜎\sigma are constants in Assumption 1, η𝜂\eta is the learning rate, fm​a​x=f​(𝐱0)−f​(𝐱∗)subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑓subscript𝐱0𝑓superscript𝐱f_{max}=f(\bm{x}_{0})-f(\bm{x}^{*}) and 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\bm{x}^{*} is the optimal global model parameters.

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Lemma 1 reveals that the smaller ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} of clients, the better the convergence rate of the model, confirming that the more frequently the clients exchange models with the server, the better the performance of the model. It is worth noting that, compared with [13] assigning a common maximum communication interval ΔΔ\Delta for all clients, it is non-trivial that we assign individual ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} for each client k𝑘k due to two-fold: First, the derivation in this paper is significantly different and thus we obtain a new convergence rate, which also affects the next derivations of selection probability and considered optimization problem. Second, a common ΔΔ\Delta makes all clients send gradients at the same frequency, which ignores the heterogeneous channel conditions of clients. On the contrary, the proposed individual ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} can adapt channel variations and multi-user diversity, i.e., allowing the clients with better channel conditions to send gradients more frequently and those with poor channel conditions to send less frequently.

Furthermore, the client selection probability {pk,t}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{p_{k,t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1} is directly related to the maximum communication interval ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} as follows.

𝔼​[Δk]=∑t=0T−1[(pk,t​∏τ=0t−1(1−pk,τ))​t].𝔼delimited-[]subscriptΔ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1delimited-[]subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptproduct𝜏0𝑡11subscript𝑝𝑘𝜏𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{k}]=\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left[\left(p_{k,t}\prod_{\tau=0}^{t-1}(1-p_{k,\tau})\right)t\right]. (7)

(7) is intractable as variables pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} are multiplied, so we approximate ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} to a tractable form by the following way. First, based on {pk,t}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{p_{k,t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1}, we can obtain the expected number of rounds in which client k𝑘k communicates with the server in total T𝑇T rounds. Subsequently, we assume that all clients exchange models with the server periodically throughout the T𝑇T rounds, so the approximate ΔksubscriptΔ𝑘\Delta_{k} can be given by

Δk′=T∑t=0T−1pk,t.superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\Delta_{k}^{\prime}=\frac{T}{\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}p_{k,t}}. (8)

Substituting (8) into Lemma 1, we can approximate the upper bound of the convergence rate by the client selection probability {pk,t}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{p_{k,t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1}, as shown in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Given the client selection probability pk,t∈{0,1,⋯,T−1},k∈{1,2,⋯,K}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡01⋯𝑇1𝑘12⋯𝐾p_{k,t}\in\{0,1,\cdots,T-1\},k\in\{1,2,\cdots,K\}, the convergence rate of asynchronous FL is approximated by

Lemma 2.

More frequent client-server model exchanges can improve convergence.

Proof.

The conclusion is apparent since increasing the value of pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} can decrease the upper bound of the convergence rate of asynchronous FL defined in (10). ∎

Lemma 3.

Fair participation of clients can improve convergence.

Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

When Δk′=ΔsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′Δ\Delta_{k}^{\prime}=\Delta for all k𝑘k in Lemma 3, i.e., each client exchanges model with the server with the same period, it is actually the age-based scheme [33] and the optimal solution is Round-Robin scheduling, i.e., each client participates in training by a sequential and alternating manner.

III-B Problem Formulation

In this paper, a joint optimization problem of probabilistic client selection and bandwidth allocation is formulated to trade off the convergence rate and total energy consumption of the asynchronous FL. Specifically, we use (10) as the metric of the convergence rate of asynchronous FL. Furthermore, the energy consumption for a single round Etsubscript𝐸𝑡E_{t} is obtained with (5), so the total energy consumption within the number of rounds T𝑇T is defined as ∑t=0T−1Etsuperscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝐸𝑡\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}E_{t}. For simplicity, we use 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} and 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} to denote {0,1,⋯,T−1}01⋯𝑇1\{0,1,\cdots,T-1\} and {1,2,⋯,K}12⋯𝐾\{1,2,\cdots,K\}, respectively. The optimization problem can be written as:

(P1):min𝒑,𝒘\displaystyle(\text{P1}):\quad\min_{\bm{p},\bm{w}}\quad ρ​T2K​∑k=1K(1∑t=0T−1pk,t)2𝜌superscript𝑇2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{\rho T^{2}}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\frac{1}{\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}p_{k,t}}\right)^{2}
+\displaystyle+ (1−ρ)​∑t=0T−1∑k=1Kpk,t​Pk​Swk,t​W​log⁡(1+Pk​hk,twk,t​W​N0)1𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝑃𝑘𝑆subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑊1subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝑊subscript𝑁0\displaystyle(1-\rho)\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{p_{k,t}P_{k}S}{w_{k,t}W\log\left(1+\frac{P_{k}h_{k,t}}{w_{k,t}WN_{0}}\right)} (11)
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad ∑k=1Kwk,t≤1,∀t∈𝒯,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1for-all𝑡𝒯\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}w_{k,t}\leq 1,\quad\quad\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall t\in\mathcal{T}, (12)
0≤wk,t≤1,∀t∈𝒯,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence0subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑡𝒯for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle 0\leq w_{k,t}\leq 1,\quad\quad\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall t\in\mathcal{T},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (13)
λ≤pk,t≤1,∀t∈𝒯,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence𝜆subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑡𝒯for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\lambda\leq p_{k,t}\leq 1,\quad\quad\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall t\in\mathcal{T},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (14)

where 𝒑={𝒑1,𝒑2,⋯,𝒑K}𝒑subscript𝒑1subscript𝒑2⋯subscript𝒑𝐾\bm{p}=\{\bm{p}_{1},\bm{p}_{2},\cdots,\bm{p}_{K}\} with 𝒑k={pk,0,pk,1,⋯,pk,T−1}subscript𝒑𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘0subscript𝑝𝑘1⋯subscript𝑝𝑘𝑇1\bm{p}_{k}=\{p_{k,0},p_{k,1},\cdots,p_{k,T-1}\} denotes the client selection probability vector, 𝒘={𝒘1,𝒘2,⋯,𝒘K}𝒘subscript𝒘1subscript𝒘2⋯subscript𝒘𝐾\bm{w}=\{\bm{w}_{1},\bm{w}_{2},\cdots,\bm{w}_{K}\} with 𝒘k={wk,0,wk,1,⋯,wk,T−1}subscript𝒘𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘0subscript𝑤𝑘1⋯subscript𝑤𝑘𝑇1\bm{w}_{k}=\{w_{k,0},w_{k,1},\cdots,w_{k,T-1}\} denotes the bandwidth allocation ratio vector, λ𝜆\lambda is the minimum client selection probability and ρ𝜌\rho is the tradeoff coefficient for bi-objective optimization problem, tending to optimize the convergence rate of asynchronous FL when ρ𝜌\rho is large and to minimize the total energy consumption when ρ𝜌\rho is small. Constraints (12) and (13) are the feasibility conditions on the bandwidth allocation, and constraint (14) ensures that each client is given at least a certain chance to participate in the asynchronous FL.

However, problem (P1) is a non-convex problem as the second term of objective is in the form of sum-of-ratios. So problem (P1) needs to be transformed into equivalently tractable problems by using suitable mathematical tools.

IV Optimal Solution for Problem (P1)

In this section, we convert problem (P1) into an equivalent parameterized subtractive-form problem and develop iterative algorithms to find the globally optimal solutions.

IV-A Fractional Programming Transform

Problem (P1) is a non-convex problem as the second term of (11) is the sum-of-ratios structure. According to [46], we transform the sum-ratio optimization problem into a parameterized subtractive-form problem as shown in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.

Denote 𝛂={𝛂1,𝛂2,⋯,𝛂K}𝛂subscript𝛂1subscript𝛂2⋯subscript𝛂𝐾\bm{\alpha}=\{\bm{\alpha}_{1},\bm{\alpha}_{2},\cdots,\bm{\alpha}_{K}\} with 𝛂k={αk,0,αk,1,⋯,αk,T−1}subscript𝛂𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘0subscript𝛼𝑘1⋯subscript𝛼𝑘𝑇1\bm{\alpha}_{k}=\{\alpha_{k,0},\alpha_{k,1},\cdots,\alpha_{k,T-1}\}, 𝛃={𝛃1,𝛃2,⋯,𝛃K}𝛃subscript𝛃1subscript𝛃2⋯subscript𝛃𝐾\bm{\beta}=\{\bm{\beta}_{1},\bm{\beta}_{2},\cdots,\bm{\beta}_{K}\} with 𝛃k={βk,0,βk,1,⋯,βk,T−1}subscript𝛃𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘0subscript𝛽𝑘1⋯subscript𝛽𝑘𝑇1\bm{\beta}_{k}=\{\beta_{k,0},\beta_{k,1},\cdots,\beta_{k,T-1}\} and 𝛄={γ1,γ2,⋯,γK}𝛄subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2⋯subscript𝛾𝐾\bm{\gamma}=\{\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2},\cdots,\gamma_{K}\}, if (𝐩∗,𝐰∗)superscript𝐩superscript𝐰(\bm{p}^{*},\bm{w}^{*}) is the optimal solution to problem (P1), there exists 𝛂𝛂\bm{\alpha}, 𝛃𝛃\bm{\beta} and 𝛄𝛄\bm{\gamma} such that (𝐩∗,𝐰∗)superscript𝐩superscript𝐰(\bm{p}^{*},\bm{w}^{*}) is also the optimal solution to the following problem with 𝛂=𝛂∗𝛂superscript𝛂\bm{\alpha}=\bm{\alpha}^{*}, 𝛃=𝛃∗𝛃superscript𝛃\bm{\beta}=\bm{\beta}^{*} and 𝛄=𝛄∗𝛄superscript𝛄\bm{\gamma}=\bm{\gamma}^{*}:

Theorem 2 transforms problem (P1) into an equivalent parameterized form (P2) by introducing additional parameters (𝜶,𝜷,𝜸)𝜶𝜷𝜸(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta},\bm{\gamma}), where problems (P1) and (P2) have the same optimal solutions (𝒑∗,𝒘∗)superscript𝒑superscript𝒘(\bm{p}^{*},\bm{w}^{*}) when (𝜶,𝜷,𝜸)=(𝜶∗,𝜷∗,𝜸∗)𝜶𝜷𝜸superscript𝜶superscript𝜷superscript𝜸(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta},\bm{\gamma})=(\bm{\alpha}^{*},\bm{\beta}^{*},\bm{\gamma}^{*}). Accordingly, problem (P2) can be solved in two layers: in the inner-layer, (𝒑∗,𝒘∗)superscript𝒑superscript𝒘(\bm{p}^{*},\bm{w}^{*}) can be obtained by solving the subtractive-form problem (P2) with given (𝜶,𝜷,𝜸)𝜶𝜷𝜸(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta},\bm{\gamma}). Then, in the outer layer, we find the optimal (𝜶∗,𝜷∗,𝜸∗)superscript𝜶superscript𝜷superscript𝜸(\bm{\alpha}^{*},\bm{\beta}^{*},\bm{\gamma}^{*}) satisfying (19).

IV-B Solving Problem (P2) Given (𝛂,𝛃,𝛄)𝛂𝛃𝛄(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta},\bm{\gamma})

Problem (P2) is further decoupled into two sub-problems, namely client selection probability optimization and bandwidth allocation. First, given (𝜶,𝜸)𝜶𝜸(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\gamma}), the client selection probability optimization problem for each client k𝑘k can be written as follows.

By solving the K𝐾K sub-problems (P3), we can obtain the optimal selection probability 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p^{*}} to problem (P2). Similarly, given (𝜶,𝜷)𝜶𝜷(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}), the bandwidth allocation problem for each round t𝑡t can be written as follows.

The optimal bandwidth allocation ratio 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\bm{w^{*}} to problem (P2) can also be obtained by solving the T𝑇T sub-problems (P4).

Now we solve problem (P3) which is a convex problem as all constraints in problem (P3) are affine. We adopt the block coordinate descent (BCD) to solve the problem. Specifically, by denoting (IV-B) as L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}, the optimal value of pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} can be obtained by setting ∂L1∂pk,t=0subscript𝐿1subscript𝑝𝑘𝑡0\frac{\partial L_{1}}{\partial p_{k,t}}=0 as

(26)

Thus each pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} can be updated alternately via (26) by assuming that other pk,jsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑗p_{k,j} (j≠t)𝑗𝑡(j\neq t) are fixed. The alternating optimization method can eventually converge to the optimal solution 𝒑∗superscript𝒑\bm{p}^{*} to problem (P3) since the problem is convex.

Problem (P4) is also a convex problem with respect to the bandwidth allocation ratio 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}, thus the Lagrangian dual method can be adopted to solve this problem optimally. where

g1​(𝒗)=max0<wk,t≤1⁡L2​(𝒘,𝒗).subscript𝑔1𝒗subscript0subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1subscript𝐿2𝒘𝒗\displaystyle g_{1}(\bm{v})=\max_{0<w_{k,t}\leq 1}L_{2}(\bm{w},\bm{v}). (29)

The second order of the Lagrangian function L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} with respect to wk,tsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k,t} is

which is negative so that L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} is concave over wk,tsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k,t} and the optimal solution can be obtained by setting ∂L2∂wk,t=0subscript𝐿2subscript𝑤𝑘𝑡0\frac{\partial L_{2}}{\partial w_{k,t}}=0. For the dual problem (28), the subgradient method is used to find the optimal Lagrangian multipliers 𝒗𝒗\bm{v}, in which each vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t} is updated as

To summarize, we optimally solve the inner-layer convex problem (P3) and (P4) given (𝜶,𝜷,𝜸)𝜶𝜷𝜸(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta},\bm{\gamma}), and then solve the outer-layer problem by the modified Newton method, where the two-layer problems are solved alternately in a loop to finally obtain the globally optimal solution to problem (P2), which is presented in Algorithm 1.

IV-D Online Implementation

So far the proposed Algorithm 1 has found the optimal selection probability and bandwidth allocation ratio. However, since the calculation of the selection probability pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} in (26) needs the probabilities of other rounds, Algorithm 1 can be operated by an offline fashion. To address this issue, we extend the algorithm to an online one. Specifically, we assume that the selection probability of each client pk,tsubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡p_{k,t} is identical in all rounds, i.e., pk,t=pksubscript𝑝𝑘𝑡subscript𝑝𝑘p_{k,t}=p_{k} for all round t𝑡t. Note that this assumption is widely used in the literature [29, 48]. Then, problem (P1) can be rewritten as

(P1′):min𝒑′,𝒘′\displaystyle(\text{P1}^{\prime}):\quad\min_{\bm{p}^{\prime},\bm{w}^{\prime}}\quad ρK​∑k=1K(1pk)2𝜌𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript1subscript𝑝𝑘2\displaystyle\frac{\rho}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\frac{1}{p_{k}}\right)^{2}
+(1−ρ)​T​∑k=1Kpk​Pk​Swk​W​log⁡(1+P​hkwk​W​N0)1𝜌𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘𝑆subscript𝑤𝑘𝑊1𝑃subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘𝑊subscript𝑁0\displaystyle\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ +(1-\rho)T\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{p_{k}P_{k}S}{w_{k}W\log\left(1+\frac{Ph_{k}}{w_{k}WN_{0}}\right)} (41)
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm{s.t.}}\quad ∑k=1Kwk≤1,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑤𝑘1\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}w_{k}\leq 1, (42)
0≤wk≤1,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence0subscript𝑤𝑘1for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle 0\leq w_{k}\leq 1,\quad\quad\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (43)
λ≤pk≤1,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence𝜆subscript𝑝𝑘1for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\lambda\leq p_{k}\leq 1,\quad\quad\leavevmode\nobreak\ \forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (44)

where 𝒑′={p1,p2,⋯,pK}superscript𝒑′subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2⋯subscript𝑝𝐾\bm{p}^{\prime}=\{p_{1},p_{2},\cdots,p_{K}\} and 𝒘′={w1,w2,⋯,wK}superscript𝒘′subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2⋯subscript𝑤𝐾\bm{w}^{\prime}=\{w_{1},w_{2},\cdots,w_{K}\}. Problem (P1′) has the same structure as problem (P1), thus we can extend the proposed Algorithm 1 to solve problem (P1′). Specifically, problem (P1′) can be transformed into a parameterized subtractive-form problem with given auxiliary parameters (𝜶,𝜷,𝜸)𝜶𝜷𝜸(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta},\bm{\gamma}) as

min(𝒑′,𝒘′)∈ℱρK​∑k=1K(1pk2−γk)+subscriptsuperscript𝒑′superscript𝒘′ℱlimit-from𝜌𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘2subscript𝛾𝑘\displaystyle\quad\min_{(\bm{p}^{\prime},\bm{w}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{F}}\quad\frac{\rho}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\frac{1}{p_{k}^{2}}-\gamma_{k}\right)+
∑k=1Kαk​(pk​Pk​S​T​(1−ρ)−βk​wk​W​log⁡(1+Pk​hkwk​W​N0)),superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘𝑆𝑇1𝜌subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘𝑊1subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘𝑊subscript𝑁0\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k}\left(p_{k}P_{k}ST(1-\rho)-\beta_{k}w_{k}W\log\left(1+\frac{P_{k}h_{k}}{w_{k}WN_{0}}\right)\right), (45)

where ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is the set of (𝒑′,𝒘′)superscript𝒑′superscript𝒘′(\bm{p}^{\prime},\bm{w}^{\prime}) satisfying constraints (42)-(44). Then the optimal wk∗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}^{*} can be given by (31), where the subscript t𝑡t in (31) is omitted. The optimal pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} can be given by

pk∗=[(2​ρK​αk​Pk​S​T​(1−ρ))13]λ1.superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]superscript2𝜌𝐾subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘𝑆𝑇1𝜌13𝜆1\displaystyle p_{k}^{*}=\left[\left(\frac{2\rho}{K\alpha_{k}P_{k}ST(1-\rho)}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\right]_{\lambda}^{1}. (46)

Here the optimal pk∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}^{*} is calculated only using the information in the current round, so the algorithm can be implemented online.

V Experimental Results

In this section, we conduct experiments to evaluate the performance of our proposed scheme.

V-A Experiment Settings

Wireless Network Settings: We consider a cell network with a radius of 100010001000 m. The server is located at the center of the network and the clients are randomly and uniformly distributed in the cell, where the path loss between each client and the server is 128.1+37.6​log10⁡(r)128.137.6subscript10𝑟128.1+37.6\log_{10}(r) (in dB) according to [49], where r𝑟r is the distance from the client to the server in kilometers. The client transmit power is set uniformly to 0.20.20.2 W. We consider orthogonal uplink channel access with total bandwidth W=5𝑊5W=5 MHz and the power spectrum density of the additive Gaussian noise N0=−174subscript𝑁0174N_{0}=-174 dBm/Hz. Unless mentioned otherwise, the main parameters of wireless networks used in the experiments are summarized in Table II.

FL Settings: We consider the learning task of training a classifier to evaluate the proposed scheme on the MNIST dataset and the CIFAR-10 dataset, respectively. MNIST is a database of handwritten digits containing 60,0006000060,000 training examples and 10,0001000010,000 test examples, the examples contain 101010 categories from the numbers “0” to “9”. CIFAR10 is a commonly image classification database containing 50,0005000050,000 training examples and 10,0001000010,000 test examples, the examples contain 101010 different objects. With the same setup as in [50], we assume that each client has an equal number of training examples and the local training datasets do not overlap with each other. Also, we consider the non-IID data distribution to better model the data heterogeneity in asynchronous FL. Specifically, we first divide the dataset into 101010 data blocks according to the label, and then further divide each data block into d⋅K10⋅𝑑𝐾10\frac{d\cdot K}{10} shards, and finally each client is assigned with d𝑑d shards with different labels. And the non-IID level of local datasets can be controlled by d𝑑d, and the smaller the value of d𝑑d, the more heterogeneous the data distribution is. We train a simple multilayer perceptron (MLP) model consisting of one hidden layer with 200200200 nodes for the MNIST dataset and this neural network’s model size is S=6.37×106𝑆6.37superscript106S=6.37\times 10^{6} bits. We set the batch size to 101010, the learning rate to 0.010.010.01 and the clients to perform 555 local iteration per communication round. We use AlexNet [51] to train the CIFAR-10 dataset and this model size is 4.57×1084.57superscript1084.57\times 10^{8} bits. We set the batchsize to 128128128, the learning rate to 0.010.010.01 and the clients to perform 111 local iteration per round.

Benchmarks: We introduce three benchmark schemes to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme: 1) Random scheme: All clients decide whether to communicate with the server with the same probability p𝑝p. 2) Greedy scheme [38, 36]: In each communication round, it selects the top k𝑘k clients with largest channel gain to participate in the model training. 3) Age-based scheme [33]: In each communication round, it selects k𝑘k clients in a sequential and alternating manner. Note that the value of k𝑘k is set to the same as the number of the selected clients in the proposed scheme for fair comparison.

V-B Evaluation of the Proposed Scheme

As mentioned in Section II, we use the coefficient ρ𝜌\rho to weigh the convergence performance and energy consumption in our optimization objective, with a larger ρ𝜌\rho focusing more on convergence and a smaller ρ𝜌\rho on energy, thus we first discuss the impact of ρ𝜌\rho on the model performance. We train a model on the MNIST dataset at a non-IID level of d=5𝑑5d=5 (each local dataset has 555 different categories). Fig. 2 shows the relationship between the test accuracy and the total energy consumption after 505050 communication rounds by varying ρ𝜌\rho from 0.010.010.01 to 0.90.90.9. We observe that the test accuracy rapidly increase with respect to total energy consumption when ρ𝜌\rho is small, i.e., when the ρ𝜌\rho is between 0.010.010.01 and 0.10.10.1. It indicates that the focus of the optimization changes from minimizing the energy consumption to increasing the convergence performance as ρ𝜌\rho increases. Fig. 3 shows the test accuracy and total energy consumption after 505050 communication rounds with respect to the value of ρ𝜌\rho. From Fig. 3, as the value of ρ𝜌\rho increases from 0.010.010.01 to 0.10.10.1, more clients participate in the model training, which although increases the total energy consumption, it enables the global model acquiring more information from clients and thus converge faster and obtain a higher test accuracy. However, when ρ𝜌\rho is larger, i.e., when ρ𝜌\rho increases from 0.10.10.1 to 0.90.90.9, the test accuracy first remains stable and then gradually decreases. This is due to the data heterogeneity of the clients and leads to large differences between local updates of the clients. Thus the global model obtained after aggregation deviates from the optimal direction of global loss decrease, and thus results in a decrease in test accuracy. Therefore, in practice, we can select ρ𝜌\rho in a suitable range, such as among 0.010.010.01 to 0.10.10.1, where we can select a larger ρ𝜌\rho for the focus of model convergence, and at the same time, we can select a smaller ρ𝜌\rho to meet a lower energy budget.

V-C Performance Comparison

To show the effectiveness of the scheme, we compare the proposed scheme with several benchmark schemes introduced in Section V-A. Fig. 4 shows the variation of the total energy consumption over 100100100 communication rounds with the average number of clients involved per round, where the number of clients is set to 101010. Fig. 5 shows the changes in total energy consumption over 100100100 communication rounds as the number of clients varies, where the client participation rate is uniformly set to 0.10.10.1. We can observe that the proposed scheme significantly reduces the energy consumption. Fig. 6 and Fig. 7 show the learning performance of four schemes under MNIST and CIFAR-10, where the non-IID level d𝑑d is set to 555 and the total number of clients participating in the model training is set uniformly for fair comparison. Specifically, the average number of clients participating per round is set to 111 or 222 in Fig. 6, and the client participation rate is uniformly set to 0.10.10.1 in Fig. 7. From Fig. 6 and Fig. 7, we can observe that the random scheme has the worst performance and the proposed scheme has the highest accuracy for the same energy consumption. This indicates that the proposed scheme effectively reduces the energy consumption by joint bandwidth allocation and probabilistic client selection.

V-D Adaptability to Varying Network Conditions

In the above experiments, we consider that the locations of clients are distributed randomly and thus clients can be fairly selected with best channel conditions in the greedy scheme. However, in practice, clients may not be highly mobile, so here we consider two scenarios with extremely distributed clients. In Scenario 1, client 1 to client 5 are distributed in an area with a radius of 100100100 m to 200200200 m from the server and the rest of the clients are randomly distributed in the cell, mimicking a scenario where some clients are always near around the server. In Scenario 2, client 1 to client 5 are distributed in an area with a radius of 900900900 m to 100010001000 m from the server and the rest of the clients are randomly distributed in the cell, mimicking a scenario where some clients always far from the server. We train the model in two scenarios using the MNIST dataset and CIFAR-10 dataset and set the average number of clients participating per round is 1, where the non-IID level d𝑑d is set to 5. Fig. 8 shows the model accuracy for both scenarios. We can observe that the greedy scheme exhibits poor model performance and even lower accuracy than the random scheme in MNIST dataset for the same energy consumption in the end of the training process, while our proposed scheme still maintains the optimal accuracy. Fig. 9 shows the total energy consumption per client under the proposed scheme and two benchmark schemes for the two scenarios with MNIST dataset. From Fig. 9, we can observe that the greedy scheme selects the extremely distributed clients multiple times in Scenario 1, while in Scenario 2, extremely distributed clients are completely ignored, indicating that the greedy scheme will only naively select the clients with good channel conditions, thus resulting in unfair client participation and making the global model drift towards local optimum. In contrast, the total energy consumption of each client in the proposed scheme is more balanced and similar to the random scheme and the age-based scheme in fairness. Meanwhile, since the proposed scheme involves channel-aware client selection, the per-client total energy consumption of the proposed scheme is much lower than that of the random scheme.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we studied asynchronous FL over wireless networks by joint probabilistic client selection and bandwidth allocation. A bound of convergence rate for asynchronous FL with probabilistic client selection was derived. Then, a joint optimization problem of probabilistic client selection and bandwidth allocation was formulated to trade off the convergence performance of the asynchronous FL and energy consumption of the clients. We proposed an iterative algorithm to find the globally optimal solution of the non-convex problem. Comprehensive experiments showed that the proposed scheme can improve both model convergence and energy efficiency.

Appendix

-A Proof of Lemma 1

We start with two definitions according to [13].

Definition 1.

Global model parameters sequence

𝒙t=𝒙0−ηK​∑k=1K∑t′=0πk,t∇Fk,t′,subscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝒙0𝜂𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′0subscript𝜋𝑘𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝑡′\displaystyle\bm{x}_{t}=\bm{x}_{0}-\frac{\eta}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{t^{\prime}=0}^{\pi_{k,t}}\nabla F_{k,t^{\prime}}, (47)

where K𝐾K is the number of clients and πk,tsubscript𝜋𝑘𝑡\pi_{k,t} is the last round where the client k𝑘k communicates with the server before round t𝑡t.

Definition 2.

Virtual sequence

𝒛t=𝒙0−∑t′=0t−1ηK​∑k=1K∇Fk,t′.subscript𝒛𝑡subscript𝒙0superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′0𝑡1𝜂𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝑡′\displaystyle\bm{z}_{t}=\bm{x}_{0}-\sum_{t^{\prime}=0}^{t-1}\frac{\eta}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\nabla F_{k,t^{\prime}}. (48)

Then we have the following lemma.

-B Proof of Lemma 3

According to Δk′superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′\Delta_{k}^{\prime} defined in (8), (10) can be rewritten as O​(1K​∑k=1K(Δk′)2)𝑂1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2O\left(\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\Delta_{k}^{\prime})^{2}\right). We assume that the total number of communications between the server and clients is fixed, i.e., ∑k=1K1Δk′=Csuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′𝐶\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{\Delta_{k}^{\prime}}=C, where C𝐶C is a constant. According to Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we can obtain the following inequality:

∑k=1K(1Δk′​Δk′)2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Delta_{k}^{\prime}}}\sqrt{\Delta_{k}^{\prime}}\right)^{2} ≤∑k=1K(1Δk′)2​∑k=1K(Δk′)2,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Delta_{k}^{\prime}}}\right)^{2}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(\sqrt{\Delta_{k}^{\prime}}\right)^{2}, (90)
KC𝐾𝐶\displaystyle\frac{K}{C} ≤∑k=1KΔk′,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′\displaystyle\leq\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Delta_{k}^{\prime}, (91)

where the equality is achieved when there exists a constant ΔΔ\Delta such that Δk′=ΔsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′Δ\Delta_{k}^{\prime}=\Delta for all k𝑘k. Then we can obtain the following inequality according to the arithmetic mean-quadratic mean inequality:

∑n=1KΔk′K≤∑n=1K(Δk′)2K,superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝐾superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2𝐾\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{K}\Delta_{k}^{\prime}}{K}\leq\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{K}(\Delta_{k}^{\prime})^{2}}{K}}, (92)

where the equality is achieved when there exists a constant ΔΔ\Delta such that Δk′=ΔsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′Δ\Delta_{k}^{\prime}=\Delta for all k𝑘k. Substituting (91) into (92), we can obtain

1C≤∑k=1KΔk′K≤∑n=1K(Δk′)2K,1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2𝐾\displaystyle\frac{1}{C}\leq\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Delta_{k}^{\prime}}{K}\leq\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{K}(\Delta_{k}^{\prime})^{2}}{K}}, (93)

which be simplified as

KC2≤∑n=1K(Δk′)2,𝐾superscript𝐶2superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2\displaystyle\frac{K}{C^{2}}\leq\sum_{n=1}^{K}(\Delta_{k}^{\prime})^{2}, (94)

where the equality is achieved when there exists a constant ΔΔ\Delta such that Δk′=ΔsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′Δ\Delta_{k}^{\prime}=\Delta for all k𝑘k. Therefore, 1K​∑k=1K(Δk′)21𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′2\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\Delta_{k}^{\prime})^{2} achieves the lower bound when Δk′=ΔsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘′Δ\Delta_{k}^{\prime}=\Delta for all k𝑘k, which yields to the same transmission period and thus fair participation of clients.

-C Proof of Theorem 2

To prove this theorem, we first introduce the auxiliary variables 𝜷={𝜷1,𝜷2,⋯,𝜷K}𝜷subscript𝜷1subscript𝜷2⋯subscript𝜷𝐾\bm{\beta}=\{\bm{\beta}_{1},\bm{\beta}_{2},\cdots,\bm{\beta}_{K}\} with 𝜷k={βk,0,βk,1,⋯,βk,T−1}subscript𝜷𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘0subscript𝛽𝑘1⋯subscript𝛽𝑘𝑇1\bm{\beta}_{k}=\{\beta_{k,0},\beta_{k,1},\cdots,\beta_{k,T-1}\} and 𝜸={γ1,γ2,⋯,γK}𝜸subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2⋯subscript𝛾𝐾\bm{\gamma}=\{\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2},\cdots,\gamma_{K}\}. Then problem (P1) can be transformed equivalently as

where ℱℱ\mathcal{F} denotes the set of (𝒑,𝒘)𝒑𝒘(\bm{p},\bm{w}) satisfying the convex constraints (12)-(14). Clearly, the optimal (𝒑∗,𝒘∗,𝜷∗,𝜸∗)superscript𝒑superscript𝒘superscript𝜷superscript𝜸(\bm{p}^{*},\bm{w}^{*},\bm{\beta}^{*},\bm{\gamma}^{*}) to problem (95) satisfies the following conditions:

Then we introduce Lagrangian multipliers 𝜶={𝜶1,𝜶2,⋯,𝜶K}𝜶subscript𝜶1subscript𝜶2⋯subscript𝜶𝐾\bm{\alpha}=\{\bm{\alpha}_{1},\bm{\alpha}_{2},\cdots,\bm{\alpha}_{K}\} with 𝜶k={αk,0,αk,1,⋯,αk,T−1}subscript𝜶𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘0subscript𝛼𝑘1⋯subscript𝛼𝑘𝑇1\bm{\alpha}_{k}=\{\alpha_{k,0},\alpha_{k,1},\cdots,\alpha_{k,T-1}\} and 𝝂={ν1,ν2,⋯,νK}𝝂subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈2⋯subscript𝜈𝐾\bm{\nu}=\{\nu_{1},\nu_{2},\cdots,\nu_{K}\} associated with constraints (96) and (97), respectively. where (𝒑∗,𝒘∗,𝜷∗,𝜸∗)superscript𝒑superscript𝒘superscript𝜷superscript𝜸(\bm{p}^{*},\bm{w}^{*},\bm{\beta}^{*},\bm{\gamma}^{*}) is the optimal solution to problem (95). Thus, the optimal (𝒑∗,𝒘∗)superscript𝒑superscript𝒘(\bm{p}^{*},\bm{w}^{*}) of problem (95) is also the solution of problem (P2) for given (𝜶,𝜷,𝜸)=(𝜶∗,𝜷∗,𝜸∗)𝜶𝜷𝜸superscript𝜶superscript𝜷superscript𝜸(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta},\bm{\gamma})=(\bm{\alpha}^{*},\bm{\beta}^{*},\bm{\gamma}^{*}), which completes the proof.
